Cicero hated and despised Epicureanism most sincerely, and one of his chief aims in undertaking his philosophical works was to stem the tide of its popularity in Italy. At the same time, as a patriot, he felt shame that the literature of his country should be destitute just where Greek was richest. He often tries by the most far-fetched arguments to shew that philosophy had left its mark on the Italian โ .peoples in early timesยน. We have seen that there were many men of culture who did not object to philosophy so long as it was taught and read in Greek To these he replies with indignation, accusing thern of being untrue to their countryยณ. It would be a glorious thing, he thinks, if Romans were no longer absolutely compelled to resort to the Greeksโด. He will not even concede that Greek is a richer tongue than Latinโธ. As for the alleged incapacity of the Roman intellect to deal with philosophica] inquiries, he will not hear of it It is only, he says, because the energy of the nation has been diverted into other channels that so little progress has been made in this direction. The history of Roman oratory is referred to in support of this opini0nโธ. If only an im- pulse were given at Rome to the pursuit of philosophy, already ou the wane in Greece, Cicero thought that it would flourish and take the place of oratory, which he believed to be expiring amid the din of civil warโท. He moreover clearly foresaw that the abolition of the old consti- tution of the state would drive many Romans in future to seek con- solation in abstract studiesโธ.

There can be no doubt that Cicero was penetrated by the belief that if he wrote on philosophy he would do his country a real serrdceโ.
